paragraphs.text:
%md

## Exploring Spark SQL Module
#### with an Airline Dataset

**Level**: Beginner
**Language**: Scala
**Requirements**: 
- [HDP 2.6](http://hortonworks.com/products/sandbox/) (or later) or [HDCloud](https://hortonworks.github.io/hdp-aws/)
- Spark 2.x

**Author**: Robert Hryniewicz
**Follow** [@RobertH8z](https://twitter.com/RobertH8z)

msg.data:
Exploring Spark SQL Module

with an Airline Dataset

Level: Beginner
Language: Scala
Requirements:
- HDP 2.6 (or later) or HDCloud
- Spark 2.x

Author: Robert Hryniewicz
Follow @RobertH8z

paragraphs.title: Introduction
paragraphs.text:
%md

In this lab you will use Spark SQL via DataFrames API in Part 1 of the lab and SQL API in Part 2 of the lab to explore an Airline Dataset. This is a very interesting dataset that is further explored in other demo notebooks.

msg.data: In this lab you will use Spark SQL via DataFrames API in Part 1 of the lab and SQL API in Part 2 of the lab to explore an Airline Dataset. This is a very interesting dataset that is further explored in other demo notebooks.

paragraphs.title: Datasets? DataFrames?
paragraphs.text:
%md

A **Dataset** is a distributed collection of data. Dataset provides the benefits of strong typing, ability to use powerful lambda functions with the benefits of (Spark SQL’s) optimized execution engine. A Dataset can be constructed from JVM objects and then manipulated using functional transformations (map, flatMap, filter, etc.). The Dataset API is available in Scala and Java.

A **DataFrame** is a Dataset organized into named columns. It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. The DataFrame API is available in Scala, Java, Python, and R. In Scala and Java, a DataFrame is represented by a Dataset of Rows. In the Scala API, DataFrame is simply a type alias of Dataset[Row]. (Note that in Scala type parameters (generics) are enclosed in square brackets.)

Throughout this document, we will often refer to Scala/Java Datasets of Rows as DataFrames. [[source](http://spark.apache.org/docs/2.0.0/sql-programming-guide.html#datasets-and-dataframes)]

msg.data:
A Dataset is a distributed collection of data. Dataset provides the benefits of strong typing, ability to use powerful lambda functions with the benefits of (Spark SQL’s) optimized execution engine. A Dataset can be constructed from JVM objects and then manipulated using functional transformations (map, flatMap, filter, etc.). The Dataset API is available in Scala and Java.

A DataFrame is a Dataset organized into named columns. It is conceptually equivalent to a table in a relational database or a data frame in R/Python, but with richer optimizations under the hood. DataFrames can be constructed from a wide array of sources such as: structured data files, tables in Hive, external databases, or existing RDDs. The DataFrame API is available in Scala, Java, Python, and R. In Scala and Java, a DataFrame is represented by a Dataset of Rows. In the Scala API, DataFrame is simply a type alias of Dataset[Row]. (Note that in Scala type parameters (generics) are enclosed in square brackets.)

Throughout this document, we will often refer to Scala/Java Datasets of Rows as DataFrames. [source]

paragraphs.title: New to Scala?
paragraphs.text:
%md

Throughout this lab we will use basic Scala syntax. If you would like to learn more about Scala, here's an excellent introductory [Tutorial](http://www.dhgarrette.com/nlpclass/scala/basics.html).

msg.data: Throughout this lab we will use basic Scala syntax. If you would like to learn more about Scala, here’s an excellent introductory Tutorial.

paragraphs.title: How to run a paragraph
paragraphs.text:
%md
To run a paragraph in a Zeppelin notebook you can either click the `play` button (blue triangle) on the right-hand side or simply press `Shift + Enter`.

msg.data: To run a paragraph in a Zeppelin notebook you can either click the play button (blue triangle) on the right-hand side or simply press Shift + Enter.

paragraphs.title: What are Interpreters?
paragraphs.text:
%md

In the following paragraphs we are going to execute Spark code, run shell commands to download and move files, run sql queries etc. Each paragraph will start with `%` followed by an interpreter name, e.g. `%spark2` for a Spark 2.x interpreter. Different interpreter names indicate what will be executed: code, markdown, html etc.  This allows you to perform data ingestion, munging, wrangling, visualization, analysis, processing and more, all in one place!

Throughtout this notebook we will use the following interpreters:

- `%spark2` - Spark interpreter to run Spark code written in Scala
- `%spark2.sql` - Spark SQL interprter (to execute SQL queries against temporary tables in Spark)
- `%sh` - Shell interpreter to run shell commands
- `%angular` - Angular interpreter to run Angular and HTML code
- `%md` - Markdown for displaying formatted text, links, and images

To learn more about Zeppelin interpreters check out this [link](https://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.5.6-incubating/manual/interpreters.html).

msg.data:
In the following paragraphs we are going to execute Spark code, run shell commands to download and move files, run sql queries etc. Each paragraph will start with % followed by an interpreter name, e.g. %spark2 for a Spark 2.x interpreter. Different interpreter names indicate what will be executed: code, markdown, html etc. This allows you to perform data ingestion, munging, wrangling, visualization, analysis, processing and more, all in one place!

Throughtout this notebook we will use the following interpreters:

  • %spark2 - Spark interpreter to run Spark code written in Scala
  • %spark2.sql - Spark SQL interprter (to execute SQL queries against temporary tables in Spark)
  • %sh - Shell interpreter to run shell commands
  • %angular - Angular interpreter to run Angular and HTML code
  • %md - Markdown for displaying formatted text, links, and images

To learn more about Zeppelin interpreters check out this link.

paragraphs.title: Verify Spark Version (should be 2.x)
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

spark.version

paragraphs.title: Download CSV flight data file
paragraphs.text:
%sh

# You will now download a subset of 2008 flights (only 100k lines)
# The full dataset may be found here: http://stat-computing.org/dataexpo/2009/the-data.html

wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/roberthryniewicz/datasets/master/airline-dataset/flights/flights.csv -O /tmp/flights.csv
echo "Downloaded!"

paragraphs.title: Move Datasets to HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh

# remove existing copies of dataset from HDFS
hadoop fs -rm -r -f /tmp/airflightsdelays

# create directory on HDFS
hadoop fs -mkdir /tmp/airflightsdelays

# put data into HDFS
hadoop fs -put /tmp/flights.csv /tmp/airflightsdelays/

msg.data: 17/02/18 06:16:42 INFO fs.TrashPolicyDefault: Moved: 'hdfs://ip-10-0-1-24.us-west-2.compute.internal:8020/tmp/airflightsdelays' to trash at: hdfs://ip-10-0-1-24.us-west-2.compute.internal:8020/user/zeppelin/.Trash/Current/tmp/airflightsdelays

paragraphs.title: Preview Downloaded File
paragraphs.text:
%sh

hadoop fs -cat /tmp/airflightsdelays/flights.csv | head

paragraphs.title: Create a DataFrame from CSV file
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

// Create a flights DataFrame from CSV file
val flights = spark.read
              .option("header", "true")                              // Use first line as header
              .option("inferSchema", "true")                         // Infer schema
              .csv("hdfs:///tmp/airflightsdelays/flights.csv")       // Read data

msg.data: flights: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [Year: int, Month: int ... 27 more fields]

26 WeatherDelay in minutes

29 LateAircraftDelay in minutes

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Part 1: Using DataFrame/Dataset API to Analyze the Airline Data

Note: in this lab DataFrame and Dataset API calls will be indistinguishable. Internally, however, *flights* are represented as DataFrames and *delayedFlights* as Datasets in the examples below.

msg.data:
Part 1: Using DataFrame/Dataset API to Analyze the Airline Data

Note: in this lab DataFrame and Dataset API calls will be indistinguishable. Internally, however, flights are represented as DataFrames and delayedFlights as Datasets in the examples below.

paragraphs.title: Show a subset of columns
Apply a filter to find flights delayed more than 15 min
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

// Create a Dataset containing flights with delayed departure by more than 15 min using "filter"
val delayedFlights = flights
                        .select("UniqueCarrier", "DepDelay")
                        .filter($"DepDelay" > 15)
                        
delayedFlights.show()

paragraphs.title: Display percentage of delayed flights
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

val numTotalFlights = flights.count()
val numDelayedFlights = delayedFlights.count()

// Print total number of delayed flights
println("Percentage of Delayed Flights: " + (numDelayedFlights.toFloat/numTotalFlights*100) + "%")

msg.data:
numTotalFlights: Long = 100000

numDelayedFlights: Long = 19587
Percentage of Delayed Flights: 19.587%

paragraphs.text:
%md

We can also create a user defined function (UDF) to determine delays.

msg.data: We can also create a user defined function (UDF) to determine delays.

paragraphs.title: Create a UDF to determine delays

msg.data:
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions.udf

isDelayedUDF: org.apache.spark.sql.expressions.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,IntegerType,Some(List(StringType)))

paragraphs.title: Create a new DataFrame with IsDelayed column
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

val flightsWithDelays = flights.select($"Year", $"Month", $"DayofMonth", $"UniqueCarrier", $"FlightNum", $"DepDelay", 
                    isDelayedUDF($"DepDelay").alias("IsDelayed"))
                    
flightsWithDelays.show(5)

%md


Note that now we have a new table with a column that indicates whether a flight is delayed or not. This will allow us to calculate percentage of delayed flights in one pass.

msg.data: Note that now we have a new table with a column that indicates whether a flight is delayed or not. This will allow us to calculate percentage of delayed flights in one pass.

paragraphs.title: Calculate percentage of delayed flights using flightsWithDelays DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

flightsWithDelays.agg((sum("IsDelayed") * 100 / count("DepDelay")).alias("Percentage of Delayed Flights")).show()

%md

As you can see above, this is a very clean way of displaying a percentage of delayed flights. UDFs are useful in creating additional functions that are commonly used.

Now let's explore our flights a bit more and find some averages.

msg.data:
As you can see above, this is a very clean way of displaying a percentage of delayed flights. UDFs are useful in creating additional functions that are commonly used.

Now let’s explore our flights a bit more and find some averages.

paragraphs.title: Find Avg Taxi-in
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

flights.select("Origin", "Dest", "TaxiIn")
        .groupBy("Origin", "Dest")
        .agg(avg("TaxiIn")
        .alias("AvgTaxiIn"))
        .orderBy(desc("AvgTaxiIn"))
        .show(10)

paragraphs.title: Find Avg Taxi-out
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

flights.select("Origin", "Dest", "TaxiOut")
        .groupBy("Origin", "Dest")
        .agg(avg("TaxiOut")
        .alias("AvgTaxiOut"))
        .orderBy(desc("AvgTaxiOut"))
        .show(10)

%md
### Part 2: Using SQL API to Analyze the Airline Data

msg.data: Part 2: Using SQL API to Analyze the Airline Data

paragraphs.title: Is there a more interactive way to display query results?
paragraphs.text:
%md

As you can see, the data displayed in Part 1 of this notebook isn't too interactive. To have a more dynamic experience, let's create a temporary (in-memory) view that we can query against and interact with the resulting data in a table or graph format. The temporary view will allow us to execute SQL queries against it.

Note that the temporary view will reside in memory as long as the Spark session is alive.

msg.data:
As you can see, the data displayed in Part 1 of this notebook isn’t too interactive. To have a more dynamic experience, let’s create a temporary (in-memory) view that we can query against and interact with the resulting data in a table or graph format. The temporary view will allow us to execute SQL queries against it.

Note that the temporary view will reside in memory as long as the Spark session is alive.

paragraphs.title: Register a User Defined Function (UDF)

msg.data: res35: org.apache.spark.sql.expressions.UserDefinedFunction = UserDefinedFunction(<function1>,IntegerType,Some(List(StringType)))

paragraphs.title: Compare Total Number of Delayed Flights by Carrier
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.sql
--- Compare Total Number of Delayed Flights by Carrier
SELECT UniqueCarrier, SUM(isDelayedUDF(DepDelay)) AS NumDelays FROM flightsView GROUP BY UniqueCarrier

msg.data:
UniqueCarrier	NumDelays
XE	1014
WN	18573

paragraphs.title: Compare Total Delayed Time (min) by Carrier
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.sql
--- Compare Total Delayed Time (min) by Carrier
SELECT UniqueCarrier, SUM(DepDelay) AS TotalTimeDelay FROM flightsView GROUP BY UniqueCarrier

msg.data:
UniqueCarrier	TotalTimeDelay
XE	47505.0
WN	978547.0

paragraphs.title: Find Average Distance Travelled by Carrier
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.sql
--- Find Average Distance Travelled by Carrier
SELECT UniqueCarrier, avg(Distance) AS AvgDistanceTraveled FROM flightsView GROUP BY UniqueCarrier ORDER BY AvgDistanceTraveled DESC

msg.data:
UniqueCarrier	AvgDistanceTraveled
XE	738.0677880571909
WN	623.7926638668864

paragraphs.title: Find Out When Most Flights Get Delayed by Day of Week
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.sql

SELECT DayOfWeek, CASE WHEN isDelayedUDF(DepDelay) = 1 THEN 'delayed' ELSE 'ok' END AS Delay, COUNT(1) AS Count
FROM flightsView
GROUP BY DayOfWeek, CASE WHEN isDelayedUDF(DepDelay) = 1 THEN 'delayed' ELSE 'ok' END
ORDER BY DayOfWeek

msg.data:
DayOfWeek	Delay	Count
1	delayed	2656
1	ok	11863
2	delayed	1799
2	ok	12911
3	ok	13260
3	delayed	1434
4	delayed	4808
4	ok	12271
5	ok	11003
5	delayed	3514
6	delayed	1878
6	ok	9407
7	ok	9698
7	delayed	3498

paragraphs.title: Find Out When Most Flights Get Delayed by Hour
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.sql

SELECT CAST(CRSDepTime / 100 AS INT) AS Hour, CASE WHEN isDelayedUDF(DepDelay) = 1 THEN 'delayed' ELSE 'ok' END AS Delay, COUNT(1) AS Count
FROM flightsView
GROUP BY CAST(CRSDepTime / 100 AS INT), CASE WHEN isDelayedUDF(DepDelay) = 1 THEN 'delayed' ELSE 'ok' END
ORDER BY Hour

paragraphs.title: Putting it all together
paragraphs.text:
%md

Now, with all these basic analytics in Part 1 and 2 of this lab, you should have a fairly good idea which flights have the most delays, on which routes, from which airports, at which hour, on which days of the week and months of the year, and be able to start making meaningful predictions yourself. That's the power of using Spark with Zeppelin -- having one powerful environment to perform data munging, wrangling, visualization and more on large datasets.

msg.data: Now, with all these basic analytics in Part 1 and 2 of this lab, you should have a fairly good idea which flights have the most delays, on which routes, from which airports, at which hour, on which days of the week and months of the year, and be able to start making meaningful predictions yourself. That’s the power of using Spark with Zeppelin – having one powerful environment to perform data munging, wrangling, visualization and more on large datasets.

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Persisting Results / Data

Finally, let's persist some of our results by saving our DataFrames in an optimized file format called ORC.

msg.data:
Persisting Results / Data

Finally, let’s persist some of our results by saving our DataFrames in an optimized file format called ORC.

paragraphs.text:
%angular

Save Modes

Mode (Scala/Java) Meaning
SaveMode.ErrorIfExists (default) When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, an exception is expected to be thrown.
SaveMode.Append When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, contents of the DataFrame are expected to be appended to existing data.
SaveMode.Overwrite Overwrite mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, existing data is expected to be overwritten by the contents of the DataFrame.
SaveMode.Ignore Ignore mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, the save operation is expected to not save the contents of the DataFrame and to not change the existing data. This is similar to a CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS in SQL.

Note: Save operations can optionally take a SaveMode, that specifies how to handle existing data if present. It is important to realize that these save modes do not utilize any locking and are not atomic. Additionally, when performing an Overwrite, the data will be deleted before writing out the new data.

msg.data:
Save Modes

Mode (Scala/Java) Meaning
SaveMode.ErrorIfExists (default) When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, an exception is expected to be thrown.
SaveMode.Append When saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, contents of the DataFrame are expected to be appended to existing data.
SaveMode.Overwrite Overwrite mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data/table already exists, existing data is expected to be overwritten by the contents of the DataFrame.
SaveMode.Ignore Ignore mode means that when saving a DataFrame to a data source, if data already exists, the save operation is expected to not save the contents of the DataFrame and to not change the existing data. This is similar to a CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS in SQL.

Note: Save operations can optionally take a SaveMode, that specifies how to handle existing data if present. It is important to realize that these save modes do not utilize any locking and are not atomic. Additionally, when performing an Overwrite, the data will be deleted before writing out the new data.

paragraphs.title: Save to ORC file
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

import org.apache.spark.sql.SaveMode

// Save and Overwrite our new DataFrame to an ORC file
flightsWithDelays.write.format("orc").mode(SaveMode.Overwrite).save("flightsWithDelays.orc")

msg.data: import org.apache.spark.sql.SaveMode

paragraphs.title: What is an ORC file format?
paragraphs.text:
%md

ORC (Optimized Row-Column) is a self-describing, type-aware columnar file format designed for Hadoop workloads. It is optimized for large streaming reads, but with integrated support for finding required rows quickly. Storing data in a columnar format lets the reader read, decompress, and process only the values that are required for the current query. Because ORC files are type-aware, the writer chooses the most appropriate encoding for the type and builds an internal index as the file is written. More information [here](https://orc.apache.org/).

msg.data: ORC (Optimized Row-Column) is a self-describing, type-aware columnar file format designed for Hadoop workloads. It is optimized for large streaming reads, but with integrated support for finding required rows quickly. Storing data in a columnar format lets the reader read, decompress, and process only the values that are required for the current query. Because ORC files are type-aware, the writer chooses the most appropriate encoding for the type and builds an internal index as the file is written. More information here.

paragraphs.title: Load back from an ORC file

paragraphs.text:
%md

We can also create permanent tables, instead of temporary views, using `saveAsTable`. The resulting table will still exist even after your Spark program has restarted.

msg.data: We can also create permanent tables, instead of temporary views, using saveAsTable. The resulting table will still exist even after your Spark program has restarted.

paragraphs.title: Save DataFrame as Permanent Table
paragraphs.text:
%spark2

flightsWithDelays.write.format("orc").mode(SaveMode.Overwrite).saveAsTable("flightswithdelaystbl")

paragraphs.title: Show Tables/Views
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.sql

SHOW TABLES

-- Note that flightsWithDelaysTbl is a permanent table instead of a temporary view!

msg.data:
database	tableName	isTemporary
default	flightswithdelaystbl	false
	flightsview	true
	linreg	true
	svepisodes	true
	wordcounts	true
	words	true

paragraphs.title: Querying a Permanent Table
paragraphs.text:
%spark2.sql

SELECT COUNT(1) AS Total from flightswithdelaystbl  -- As you can see, there's no difference in querying a temporary view vs a permanent table

msg.data:
Total
100000

paragraphs.title: Final Words
paragraphs.text:
%md

This should get you started working in Scala with DataFrame, Dataset and SQL Spark APIs that are part of the Spark SQL Module. You should now have the basic tools and code samples to start working on your own data sets: from brining in/downloading datasets, to moving them from local storage to HDFS, to transforming datasets into Spark DataFrames/Datasets/temporary views, querying the data, performing basic calcuations, visualizing, and finally persisiting your results. That's a great start!

You should now have the basic tools and code samples to start working on your own data sets: from brining in/downloading datasets, to moving them from local storage to HDFS, to transforming datasets into Spark DataFrames/Datasets/temporary views, querying the data, performing basic calcuations, visualizing, and finally persisiting your results. That’s a great start!

paragraphs.title: Additional Resources
paragraphs.text:
%md

We hope you've enjoyed this introductory lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](http://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP2/HDP-2.5.0/bk_spark-component-guide/content/ch_developing-spark-apps.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](http://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP2/HDP-2.5.0/bk_zeppelin-component-guide/content/ch_using_zeppelin.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.
